channel.title: NPR Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Mart√≠nez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.

item.title: Trump says he's lifting sanctions on Syria, confusing some allies in Israel
item.description: President Trump says he's dropping sanctions against Syria, which led to celebrations in the streets of Damascus. But in Israel, many are wondering where they stand with their neighbor.

item.title: RFK Jr. stands by deep cuts to health budget during contentious hearings
item.description: Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. is standing firm on the sweeping cuts to the Department of Health and Human Services, cuts he says were suggested by Elon Musk and his DOGE team.

item.title: NYT columnist Thomas Friedman sees 'creative possibilities' from Trump's Mideast trip
item.description: New York Times columnist Thomas Friedman says President Trump "made a very good move" in meeting with Syria's interim president and announcing he would lift sanctions on Israel's neighbor.

item.title: A Texas abortion ban sponsor aims to clarify when doctors can do the procedure
item.description: Since abortion became almost entirely illegal in Texas in 2021, the state has seen a significant rise in the number of women who die in pregnancy or after giving birth. A new bill aims to change that.

item.title: Newly published stories show a different side of Ian Fleming and Graham Greene
item.description: The latest issue of "The Strand Magazine" contains rare stories by the iconic midcentury writers Ian Fleming and Graham Greene.

item.title: 'Being dismissed for being different': Adam Duritz on new music with Counting Crows
item.description: In 1993, Adam Duritz and his band Counting Crows took roots-rock to new heights with their debut August and Everything After. More than 30 years later, they offer a new album, cut from the same cloth.

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: A look at relations between Israel and Syria, U.S. Supreme Court to hear arguments over birthright citizenship, House Republicans continue budget negotiations despite tensions within party.

item.title: Some see Gov. Newsom shifting to the center ahead of possible presidential run
item.description: As California Gov. Gavin Newsom announces reductions to health care for migrants in the country illegally, some say that he's moving to the political center ahead of a possible 2028 presidential run.

item.title: Trump budget proposal would end energy assistance program for low-income Americans
item.description: President Trump's budget proposal would completely eliminate a program that helps about 6 million low-income households heat and cool their homes. Supporters of the program hope Congress will save it.

item.title: Afghan refugee discusses Trump administration's ending of temporary protections
item.description: NPR's Leila Fadel speaks with Haris Tarin, a refugee who fled Afghanistan 30 years ago, about the Trump administration ending temporary protected status for Afghans in the U.S.
